statement.text: Acute renal artery occlusion causes renal infarction presenting with flank pain and hematuria, requiring urgent diagnosis and consideration of revascularization (endovascular or surgical) within 90-180 minutes for renal salvage.

explanation.intuition: When blood supply to a kidney suddenly stops, that kidney starts dying within hours. Unlike cold organs kept for transplant, a kidney at body temperature (warm ischemia) tolerates only 90 minutes to 3 hours before permanent damage.
explanation.key_insight: The kidney tolerates warm ischemia poorly. Revascularization within 90 minutes maximizes renal salvage; beyond 3-6 hours, the benefit diminishes significantly. Bilateral occlusion or solitary kidney is a surgical emergency.
explanation.technical_details: Causes: embolism (cardiac source, aortic atheroma), thrombosis (dissection, trauma, hypercoagulable), iatrogenic. Presentation: sudden flank pain, nausea/vomiting, hematuria, LDH elevation. Diagnosis: CTA or MRA. Management: anticoagulation (all patients), endovascular thrombectomy/thrombolysis, surgical embolectomy/bypass. Timing: best outcomes <90-180 min, consider intervention up to 6 hours if renal function important. Bilateral or solitary kidney: true emergency requiring immediate intervention.

clinical_features.warm_ischemia_tolerance: 90-180 minutes optimal, consider intervention up to 6 hours
clinical_features.diagnosis: CTA or MRA showing filling defect/occlusion

clinical_pearls: Kidney tolerates warm ischemia only 90-180 minutes
LDH elevation is a sensitive marker for renal infarction
Bilateral or solitary kidney occlusion is a surgical emergency
